We performed extensive HMLP-MD simulations around the Phase I–II boundary, with different starting configurations, to determine candidate structures and phase stability of H 2 Phase II. At 150 K and 20 GPa, the orientations of the H 2 molecular axes are almost randomly distributed along different directions, indicating Phase I with freely rotating molecules. Upon compression to the high pressure of 80 GPa and cooling to a low temperature of 50 K, the material transforms to an orientationally ordered phase in which the molecular rotations are restricted (Fig. 1). By carefully comparing it with candidate structures proposed by ab initio calculations, we find that the lattice and molecular ordering is close to P2 1/ c-24, which has been one of the most thoroughly studied and strongest candidate for Phase II
